Description: Glazed composition scaraboid; back in form of Black African head, with details crudely cut with blade; hair indicated by cross-lines, straight line across forhead, crudely cut out facial features; very flat profile; underside decorated with representation of winged griffin walking to right, with tail curled up; motif likely stamped rather than incised; longitudinally pierced; glaze lost; core greenish tinge; eroded surface.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie (probably)
Curator's comments: Winged mythological creatures are commonly depicted on scarabs and scaraboids at Naukratis (on this production, see Webb forthcoming). This piece belongs to a type which was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-103, 106-107, Type XXVIII A, subtype A116-117, see especially A116 for this piece). Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implication for dating, in R. Thomas (ed.), The Naukratis workshop, held at the British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 26)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p. 97, Type XXVIII A116)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OD.069) (phase 3)
